137227701.review:
Disorienting, and crudely difficult.

The default video resolution was wrong, yet there's a resolution option called "auto". The game doesn't minimize. The controls make no sense. To start you press enter, but confusingly enter is space, and there's mouse input which activates buttons no matter where you click. Shift is run, but it's practically the same speed as walking. The music is messy, and the sound cue at the end of a level is jarring. There being multiple objectives can be confusing. The story and world make no sense, and the view constantly rotating is sickening. The flashes of white light are pointlessly blinding (grey would have [i]looked[/i] the same, and worked fine).

Sometimes you can pass through the lasers, but they look pretty much the same regardless of whether they're in a state that will kill you or not. Underwater lasers kill you, how is that immersive? I guess you could say that the lasers were immersed, but I wasn't. One of the most awkward mechanics I've ever seen in a game is trying to move down a tunnel alongside the lasers, but your character can't move [i]alongside[/i] the lasers because it'll only travel at an angle, so you're constantly tapping the arrow keys - it feels like poor design rather than a fun challenge.

The gameplay in general is confusing. Every few steps, the world suddenly flips around (and the music suddenly changes), but it all looks the same, so you don't know which way you're going. I got lost frequently (and stuck; it feels bizarre to get stuck on a 2D platformer). Some rocks you're supposed to stand on, while others will just get you killed because you'll fall through them. Enemies arrive from off-screen and kill you in about a tenth of a second. The levels aren't [i]level[/i], they're all warped (almost beyond playability). You can never line up a jump because every step you take disorients the entire screen.

The screen doesn't show enough of the world around you. Sometimes you just have to guess what you're supposed to do, like assuming you can jump to something off-screen. To add to the frustration of the screen rotating (when there's dangers everywhere next to you) is that your character will keep moving when you don't want it to, so you have to wait and see if it strays into the danger - there might be a moment of judgement to trying to manage this sliding mechanic, but I found it really annoying to have to do. The old Mario games were far more satisfyingly responsive in comparison.

The game is absolutely full of noob traps that disrupt the flow of gameplay - you'd never complete even a small slice of this in one go without dying, you'd have to find out the hard way all the ridiculous things that kill you. What on Earth was the point of making the character cute if you're just going to kill it off like that every few seconds? Who would I recommend this to? I feel like dying is meaningless if you're essentially forced into it around every other corner.

There aren't enough checkpoints between the clunky parts of the game. It's a dreary experience having to go through them over and over just to go through more, and expecting even more of the same ahead. Even on the (few) bits that aren't disorienting, having to dodge multiple enemies (if not waves of them) is still really awkward. The gravity isn't even consistent - some of the ground will attract your character, but some of it won't. Some of the enemies don't even [i]move[/i] consistently. 

It's more chaotic than skillful. Would anyone even enjoy spreedrunning it? I don't know why this game has a "casual" tag, it's extremely sweaty. I'm amazed at how many issues they packed into such a simple looking game. As cheap cartoonish platformers go, BEEP was far better. I don't remember the Mario Gameboy games having these nonsense mechanics; I'd rather go back and play Super Mario Land 2 (released in 1992) honestly.

136405146.review:
I both adore and hate this game. We took turns with my soulmate in playing [i]Airscape[/i], because sooner than later your head is gonna get dizzy from it.

We are playing as Orange octopus on a quest of saving its family from a clutches of some mean alien abductors! As we go through the levels in 18 zones we have to save sea critters as they are needed for our progression. Good thing is that we don't have to collect every one of them in the respective zone as the next one opens with a lesser number. Pretty convenient with harder levels.
Once we save our otcopus siblings they can be used in the game, some of the levels are even better suited for their specific abilities (although it should be possible to complete each level with every octopus, I am not gonna test it for sure). Mind you, the last ultimate Boss fight will be Orange's duty which doesn't have any special skills.

The game description doesn't lie - [i]ultra-challenging[/i]. Yes. It's very, VERY MUCH challenging. I can't possibly stress enough how challenging it really is. Don't be fooled by its colorful and cute graphics, because you are gonna get smashed, squashed, blasted, minced, disintegrated, eaten or drowned in acid on a regular basis. It's [i]fast-paced[/i]. Yes, you need to be quick, because most of the hazardous things around actively seek to destroy you. You are left with only a fragment of a second to make a jump or slide or run and most of the time you are not gonna make it. Majority of the levels can't be done on a first try, because you are going blindly ahead and you are gonna meet some nasty surprises on the run. Practice makes perfect.

With a high probability you will get motion sickness from [i]Airscape[/i], because of the frantic rotation that happens all the time! There isn't much you can do with it. You can lower the screen rotation rate, which will seem like a good idea at the beginning, but later in the game you will get in some tight spots because of it. What is mandatory to know when controlling your octopus is that you move where you "look". So as the screen rotates you can suddenly move the other way and die. You can center your view by a dedicated keyboard button, but realizing where exactly you are will just rob you of a precious time. Also the rotation actually helps your octopus to gain momentum in quicker sequences. In the end we set it back to normal.

As for the difficulty, I will repeat yet again, it's high. Each level has usually two or three checkpoints from which you are gonna start when you die. Sometimes it doesn't seem enough though and some sequences are quite punishing, frustrating even. In such a case it is best to take a break from the game. After all, we were playing through it with combined powers since 2020.

I think [i]Airscape[/i] deserves a recommendation although it's certainly not for everyone and those who decide to play it can feel pretty miserable from time to time. But all of it will be forgotten once you clear some hard levels and then you will strive for more. You have been warned.

130244762.review:
As a deep-sea octopus kidnapped by a mechanical alien race, you must jump, dodge, and swim through a skybound environment full of floating islands, water formations, and robotic terrors. The controls are simple and easy to grasp, and the unique physics and gravity mechanics make this game stand out from the rest. 

The graphics in this game are crisp and the atmosphere is captivating. It is hard not to be mesmerized by the vibrant colors and level design. Furthermore, the soundtrack is absolutely amazing, and it perfectly accompanies the gameplay. The sound effects are also very immersive, and make you feel as if you are in the game.

The levels are extremely challenging, and each one gets more difficult as you progress. However, Airscape offers a great balance between difficulty and fun. The start of the game is quite soothing and enjoyable to play, and the middle of the game is perfectly balanced. It is only towards the end of the game that the difficulty ramps up, making for a very intense and rewarding experience. 

Overall, Airscape is a great game for anyone looking for a unique, challenging platformer. The gameplay is engaging and the levels are intense and hard to master. The graphics, soundtrack, and sound effects are all top-notch and make this game one of a kind. If you're looking for an intense, addicting platformer, Airscape is the perfect choice.

99979725.review:
Probably one of the most creative platformers I've ever played that thoroughly expands on what the genre is capable of with an utterly adorable and charming aesthetic with cute octopuses and a pretty excellent soundtrack.

However everything this game gets so very, very right is completely shot down by the actual gameplay itself. I have no problems with hard games: dying, losing and retrying is a huge part of the fun for me when I play them but from my experience this is the wrong kind of hard. Early on the game is quite fun and you can easily get to grips with the gameplay but it progresses in difficulty extremely quickly; this is mainly due to the controls being incredibly slippery thanks to your octopus' momentum so you're constantly sliding into hazards. The game's physics are also shoddy, sometimes the game reacts the way you expect it to but if you're on a moving or spinning platform then I hope RNG is on your side because sometimes when you jump you will just get flung into a hazard or out of the stage with zero warning thus causing you to suffer a cheap death. It's a precision platformer yet the controls and physics lack precision, which isn't good.

But not only that, your hitbox feels surprisingly massive as there are far too many times where I should be safe only to get killed or where I clearly jumped over an obstacle but it somehow counted as a death anyway. The game also has a bad habit of introducing new mechanics and level design without that "safety net" most other platformers use to quickly ease you in, so you're expected to know exactly what to do right away otherwise you die yet another cheap death. More often than not it's something ridiculous like having to fling yourself a great distance from a body of water or a platform that rockets you up into the ceiling and you have to tilt it right otherwise, you guessed it, you die. Those sound great on paper and they should be in practice but in actuality they are infuriatingly hard and stupendously inconsistent to the point I lost my temper in world 4.

While I don't play many platformers, I actually like them quite a bit but Airscape just felt horribly sloppy to play, it's like the developer tried aiming for Super Meat Boy difficulty without the incredibly tight and responsive controls and a much greater overuse of poorly placed hazards. I feel It's the kind of hard game where the thought process was to make a hard game that people will die on all the time which is unlike most good hard game which are made to be challenging, exhilarating and making you feel like a champ when you overcome those trials; I never once felt that during my time in Airscape - I just felt like the game was simply wasting my time with BS artificial difficulty.

I honestly don't understand why Airscape is so highly rated, for me it became an absolute chore after a single hour and I REALLY wanted to like this game because I adore its style, aesthetic, the cute octopuses and its amazingly creative approach to platforming but I just felt I was constantly kicked in the shins and I really don't want to play anymore of it. I feel if this game took a more chilled out, relaxed and zen approach to its gameplay with a greater emphasis on the puzzle aspects to perfectly fit its aesthetic then I would love Airscape with a burning passion. But as it stands, unless you want to torment yourself with a needlessly hard game that feels almost trial and error, I have to give this a firm thumbs down.

[b]tl;dr:[/b] This game is not perfect, but it's absolutely worth the price.
[h1]Full Review[/h1]
[b]Gameplay:[/b] As you are probably aware, this game is extremely difficult. (I have also played Celeste, another notoriously hard platformer, and I can say that this one is harder.) Simply beating this game is a real accomplishment. The main skill you'll need is enough patience to not ragequit when you die for the 45th time on a single level.
[b]Aesthetics (Graphics and Soundtrack):[/b] The art of this game is very well polished. There are a multitude of different areas, and all of them look unique. I particularly like the contrast between the menacing-looking black and red hazards with the bright, almost cartoonish appearance of the player character. The music is not memorable but still good and it fits together well with the rest of the game.
[b]Cost:[/b] I got this game on a 90% sale, for only 49 cents, which almost feels like stealing to me. (For a time I considered uninstalling this game then buying it again just to support the developers). I've seen it go on 90% sales several times before and I'm sure it will again if you want to wait, although I think it's worth the money even at full price.
[b]Motion Sickness:[/b] One final note, because I've seen a lot of people complain about how this game is nauseating to play. In the settings there is a slider that changes how much the camera rotates with the player. At one end the camera will not rotate at all, and at the other end it will rotate with the player. The default setting is precisely in the middle, which is highly disorienting. Just know that it doesn't have to be that way.

I really wish I could recommend Airscape, because it has so much going for it. I love the theme of it, and I usually don't mind difficult challenges where you're allowed to repeat the same section over and over until you get it right (so long as it's not in a long narrative game, where it shatters immersion).

But the way the rotating screen affects the physics is something I just can't get past on the harder levels. It can lengthen or shorten a jump massively, and it affects you in mid-air in ways I find impossible to compensate for. The fan physics are also very idiosyncratic – jumping at the same time seems to lower your height, and sometimes they randomly launch you up very fast, but I've not been able to figure out why. When you're trying to dodge random bullet spreads and hitscan sniper shots at the same time, it pushes the experience into the territory of "If I ever get past this part, it'll be pure dice-rolling luck", and that's where I check out.

Finally played this all the way through, and i had a lot of fun. controls are tight and feel good. the game does a really great job at continually establishing and building on each mechanic it introduces to keep creating new challenges for the player, even segments that look similar to previous ones on the surface have enough additions to them that no two levels ever feel the same. the gravity mechanics are fun to play around with and used very creatively throughout. that said, some of the level gimmicks are better than others. in particular moving in 0 gravity does not have good control like the rest of the game and feels more like making suggestions as to what your character should do rather than moving them. visual design could be better at points too, sometimes (though not commonly) making it difficult to see and react to all obstacles on screen. also there are a few levels where jumping on a moving platform causes a glitch where your character shoots forward and this caused a few deaths, though this only occured in a few very specific places and only rarely, so you probably wont even see this happen. not an easy game, i died well over a 1000 times by the end so be aware of that.

overall it has its issues, but id recommend anyone who likes platformers to give this a go, its a great game and would be well worth even double the small price they ask for it.

83321616.review:
There was no real reason as to [i]why[/i] I installed this game in the first place, apart from I noticed it on sale currently and that it was in my library already.  The hand drawn art and random title is what pulled my interest secondly.

Going into the game blind, you are introduced to a character using basic controls for forward and backward motion, rotating your camera as you zoom through what looks like a small pond, ocean, lake..something.  And then something happens.  Even more thrown off from the events, you're transported into a seemingly 2D platforming side-scroller, with a (literal) twist.

What I would describe as a mix of Super Meat Boy meets Super Mario Galaxy, [b]Airscape - The Fall of Gravity[/b] is a cute cartoony world that's a lot of fun to just move around in and take in the scenery, but also slaps you in the face with some difficult platforming gameplay.  The musical score and sound effects are also a pleasure and it was neat to hear the music muffled when you are swimming through the water!

There's definitely an element of motion sickness in this game but it also offers controls to easily offset the screen shake and rotation.

I thought it would be a fun, relaxing game.  I ended up getting pissed off, but still having fun!

79437120.review:
Challenging platforming game with a lovely feel!

The variation in design for each of the worlds is great, as is the actual level design. It's certainly the best take on "2d Super Mario Galaxy" that I've seen, and I understand the comparisons to Super Meat Boy. It absolutely does continue to get harder until the very last few worlds, which all took me quite a while ;).

Also, the option for how fast to rotate the screen is a nice touch - I find that having it move faster bothers me less, as it stays more consistent with the orientation of my character. But if the rotation really bothers you, you'll find out quickly, so you can always ask for a refund.

Pros:
+ Solid, Unique Platforming Experience
+ Charming Style
+ Varied Mechanics/Level Design
+ Secret/Bonus Levels
+ Great Music!!
+ A lot of content for the price - took me 10 hours to complete it

+/- Don't expect it to be easy

Cons:
- The rotation *might* make you sick
- The physics are sometimes a little slippery (you can get momentarily stuck jumping on angled surfaces, and stuff like that)

Edit: Changed a couple things since beating it :)

I bought this game on sale for around 1 euro, so my expectations were not high at all. At first the game was fun; a cinematic story intro, a simple but beautiful overall design, entertaining mechanics and enough levels to play. For the amount of money I paid for this game, it’s somewhat stunning how good it is at some aspects. However, the real downside of this game for me was that the movement system felt clumsy and some collisions were headache worthy. Furthermore, the new mechanics in every level were sometimes a bit too much. I like to speed run games like these, but in this game speed running will often result in you dying due to the massive number of hostile environments or CPU’s. Together with the sometimes, mostly in water, clumsy movement system, this can destroy all your fun while playing and turn it into what was for me a somewhat rage-ish / annoyed feeling. Therefore, the many maps do not attract and feel more like a big barrier. I tried to play this game several times, but every time it resulted in me rage quitting because I am stuck at the same level for 10 minutes because I die of that same prop repeatedly. 

In a nutshell, the game is worth my money, it is fun at first and stunning with the simplistic but beautiful game design. For me it resulted in an annoying walkthrough with Super Mario Bros feelings but then worse because of the movement system. If you can die multiple times in a row and don’t rage, this game will probably be amazing, but unfortunately, I already throw keyboards when I die in CSGO, so GG for me.

This game tries to be kinda like Super Meat Boy, in that levels are bit-sized and varying anywhere from slightly to rather difficult. That, combined with lotsa polish and pretty good level design, would make me think I'd like this game.

But, it just failed to hook me. 

If I had to put my finger on something, it'd be the loose/floaty movement of the character. It's just not satisfying nor as tight as Super Meat Boy's controls are. And oftentimes I felt the camera was *way* too zoomed-in, leaving me feeling claustrophobic whilst sometimes dying due to not being able to see what was coming up ahead. The dramatic, orchestral soundtrack got monotonous really fast, and often did not fit the vibe of what was happening on-screen.

So is this a decent, and dare I even say, a good game? It sure is.. But not quite good enough, especially when faced with the competition of other, much better platformers out there that are all vying for your time.

Cute little platformer that's definitely worth your wallet (especially when it's on sale for 90% off). Controls are very simple, but the option of playable characters and the different mechanics the game uses in both obstacles and level design definitely kept it interesting. 

The game itself is pretty difficult, but the short levels and fair checkpoint system keep it from becoming unfair (besides a handful of levels, but the optional level choices make them only a necessity if going for a 100% completion).

The orchestral soundtrack is probably the best part of this game; it perfectly sets the mood for the different areas and is amazing in its own right.

Had a lot of fun with this one. I'll give it a 7/10, but I still HIGHLY recommend buying this game just because of how affordable it is. Put it in your wishlist and wait for a 90% sale, which happens very often, and get a great deal for this great game.

53760333.review:
This game is quite poor, because its lack of varied threats means the levels soon become a "Dodge mines placed in this place! Now dodge mines based in THIS place! Now dodge a truckload of mines whilst being shot at!" I don't have very good screenshots, but this is what you can start to expect:
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=784453748
and this has moving wheels of death on moving platforms, but does not have homing attacks too (those come later in the stage.... agh, this was painful to play)

It has its ups - five characters, each unique (one can dash, one can slow time, one jumps super-high, and I can't remember the last two) and every level is playable with each one - but this isn't enough to offset the poor level design. This isn't helped by the game design: frequent checkpoints but one hit sends you back. This means you can't use invincibility frames and take some HP damage to get through tough sections - no, you have to work out how to do them. And then you have to work out how to do the next section. Aaaand the next.

[i]And then![/i] You have to replay them to collect the collectibles. Most platformer have a principle of 'one level unlocks the next,' and most platformers also have bonus collectibles that usually unlock little of note. However, this game's progression is based on how many collectibles you've collected (=> in-universe, critters you've saved, but this game has next to no plot so don't expect anything). On the plus side, this means if a group of levels takes your fancy you can pick up all the (quite hard to get...) collectibles and skip some levels you dislike. On the negative side, if you're struggling with the game, it just becomes unfriendly to play. I genuinely would have completed it if it weren't for the collectibles... but aaargh. :/ This unlocking scheme could work, but it didn't.

Oh, and the game focuses on you basically jumping in and around moving timed platforms to avoid moving timed attacks - you have no attacks or anything. This is fine, but I thought I'd mention it. This works, if everything else is polished enough (there's a lengthy section in Out There Somewhere that occurs before you get a weapon) - but this isn't polished and isn't fun.

I would write more but this game really isn't worth my effort. I haven't finished it (got about 80% through), but have no intention of ever completing the remaining 20%.

I will say one thing - it is cheap. But if you want a cheap, good, platformer, check out Out There Somewhere, which is just better in every respect. Like, literally every way. I can highly reccomend that game for its fun level design, interesting puzzles, and it's just absolutely better. https://store.steampowered.com/app/263980/Out_There_Somewhere/
I also wrote a review on that, if you're interested: https://steamcommunity.com/id/aidenpons/recommended/263980 Go play that game instead, not this one.

If you want to obtain 100% achievements, be prepared to sink quite some time into the game, as a lot of levels will take many failed attempts to master.

If you're a hardcore platformer fan you might still like this game, even though it's difficult for the wrong reasons, but a casual player would probably get frustrated by the controls sooner rather than later and give up.

51080141.review:
Airscape - The Fall of Gravity is a cutesy platformer that starts out simple but soon has you hurling your controller or keyboard out the window as you hurl your adorable octopus friend into yet another laser/robot/infinite void. 

The artwork and sound design is most certainly excellent, but for most people it will be the challenge of the game that either keeps them coming back or turns them off immediately. As expected for a game like this, there are some frustrating checkpoints, dizzying camerawork that can end up being downright confusing and the odd area where it appears you need more than a healthy dose of luck to progress.

That said, if you're a fan of games like Super Meat Boy then I certainly have no qualms about recommending this, as the vast majority of the platforming does a good job of getting you to perfect the timing on each individual series of jumps and turns, and have you feeling great when you make it.

I collected around 2 out of the 3 on every level on average and it still wasn't enough. So that means you need to go around these levels trying to go out of your way to collect these hidden random items on these confusing maps that have no direction and without any map marker or anything showing where they are for no reason other than to inflate game length. I literally spent 5 min going around 1 level to find the one remaining one. And in a good game they would make that a collectible for extra achievements or bonus art gallery images or whatever, but for here for no reason they force you to. If they didn't add that stupid poorly constructed unnecessary game design the game would be just "ok". But for having to watch walkthroughs to find missing random collectibles to progress in a reaction based 1 hit platformer is just nonsensical. 4/10.

The biggest issue I had with this game is the fact that the devs chose to make the camera so close up. It makes navigating levels very trial and error (as apposed to Super Meatboy where you get a chance to look the level over and anticipate what's next), and it also makes enemies/deaths all the more random. But what really got me was that there is a level, pretty deep into the game, where the camera is brought back to a reasonable position. Why then? Why not the whole way through? My only thought was that if the player could see the levels as a whole, it would be more obvious that each level has the design nuance of a 6 year-old's paper mache project. 45930402.review:
I really like this game. The platforming is hard enough to remain challenging but is never too hard.
The various octopi control reasonably well for the most part and the warping gravity is very well done. What is annoying sometimes is that really simple stuff like jumping on small stepping stones while running is a bit difficult, thus sometimes making getting to the timed orbs more of a challenge than it should be.
In the first 15 minutes I struggled a bit with finding the right setting of how fast the world spins to avoid motion sickness, but after I tweaked the settings I can play for extended periods without feeling queasy.
My biggest grime with the game is actually the lack of explanation of what your goals are. For instance, I had to find out about the existence of the timed orb in the online discussions - before that I was getting really annoyed about not being able to find the last orb. However, not being able to get to each orb does not preclude you from progressing further into the game so no harm done.
I agree with some online discussions that the cute graphics might give you the wrong impression what the target audience of this game is. I originally bought it for my 4 year old daughter, but her young brains can't handle the visuals at all. This game looks like it is for little kids or casual gaming, but in reality is more suitable for people who like a platforming challenge with a focus on controlling movement.

45886081.review:
He de admitir que cuando empecé a jugar a "Airscape - The Fall of Gravity" no esperaba demasiado de este título. Sin embargo, a medida que iba pasando niveles, iba también dándome cuenta que estaba ante un título realmente bueno.
Gráficamente colorido y con diseños cuidados, no será seguramente uno de esos títulos que te dejen boquiabierto por su espectacular estilismo, pero ni lo pretende ni lo necesita, pues su fuerte no lo encontrarás en este apartado.
La Banda Sonora, agradable, no te sorprenderá por sus melodías pegadizas, pero acompañan al juego de manera correcta y, además, te sorprenderá con algunos detalles como la atenuación y distorsión de la misma cuando te sumerjas en el agua. Detalles que nos dicen del cariño y el cuidado depositados en este título.
La jugabilidad, esta vez sí, es el apartado estrella en este juego, donde unos controles intuitivos y difícilmente mejorables, serán una delicia a disfrutar durante los 18 mundos, variados, llenos de enemigos y con un diseño excepcional de que consta el título. Un juego largo, cuya dificultad tiene una curba ascendente y gradual, y que representará un auténtico reto para aquellos que lo quieran acabar por completo.
El poder elegir entre diferentes calamares que iremos desbloqueando, cada uno de ellos con unas cualidades distintas, lo harán todavía más interesante. El conseguir todos los logros, será una taréa complicada pero factible, y disfrutarás haciéndolo si eres un amante de los plataformas y los retos.
Por todo ello, a pesar de no ser un juego demasiado conocido entre las masas, se merece estar en un puesto alto dentro de los plataformas, por no contar con defectos destacables y, sin embargo, mostrarnos una jugabilidad de un nivel difícilmente alcanzado por otros títulos de este género. Altamente recomendado, sin duda.

NOTA: 8/10

I loved this game. When I first bought the game when it was on sale for maybe 50c, I expected it to be one of the worse games that would take a spot in my Steam library, since usually poor quality games would go on sale for so cheap. I didn't play for a few months since I bought it, but one day I thought:

'Man, the games I usually play are getting a bit boring... why not give this game a try? I haven't even played it yet!'

I don't regret that decision.

I admit, I did turn off rotation after a while, as it just wasn't for me. But as I progressed into the game, I discovered a treasure trove of levels that feel like they were designed just for me. With difficult 2D platforming games being my favourie genre, this game suited my tastes perfectly. Especially in the later levels. The final zones gave me stress, but also gave me a challenge I enjoyed. The music was with me all the way on the journey as well.

If you liked Super Meat Boy, you probably found enjoyment in the steep difficulty curve, the controls and the collectable bandages found every few levels. If you liked Super Mario Galaxy and/or the sequel, you probably enjoyed the game mechanics of shifting gravity and jumping from one 'planet' to the next in each level to progress.

If either or both (especially both) of the above statements are true to your tastes in gaming, please do grab Airscape - The Fall of Gravity. You will have a great adventure, even if you do get stressed from time to time. I guarantee it.

43392050.review:
Airscape is a 2d platformer with a rotating world mechanic as seen in numerous other indie 2D platformers.   You play a jellyfish abducted by aliens.  Your role is to traverse the levels in the game although it's unclear why, avoiding robot lawnmowers and mines, spinning the world around as part of the mechanic so you can get to the end-of-level pad. 

A second bonus dynamic to the game is underwater areas where you can swim around, which forms part of the pathway to complete each level.  The gameplay is primarily not puzzle solving but rather just timing and dodging enemies and judging the right times and places to jump from, despite the swimming and world-rotation mechanics.

Graphics and gameplay are quite fluid although many have complained about motion sickness as the game can induce this.   The developers didn't go the cheap "retro pixel" route, although at the end of the day the game is still limited to being a platformer on PC.   While this is certainly one of the better platformers out on PC today, the gameplay itself quickly becomes a boring let down as there's just too many annoying timing challenges.  If there were only 10 games on Steam, I'd recommend this, but there's well over 10,000, and not everyone can be recommended over all the others.

42926998.review: At first glance, this game seems like just another of those generic platformers that are abundant on Steam. In reality, you can see that it tries hard to be more than that, but some design mechanics prevent it from being a great platformer. Instead, it’s just an average, good one. In this game, you control an octopus through 63 levels in total. The camera rotates a lot, and it can make you dizzy. It makes your character a bit harder to control, but nothing serious. The game also has swimming, and it isn’t good. You need to rotate (which also rotates the camera) in order to go sideways, and it isn’t a fun experience. I completed the game to 101%, according to the achievement, so I can tell that most of the game has the right amount of difficulty, but there’s some sections that are annoying as hell. And guess what, most of them involved swimming. You have less control and more cheap deaths. The checkpoint system is welcome, but I felt that should have been more of them. Some enemies are also annoying to deal with and rely a bit on luck. And perhaps that’s the main problem I have with this game: many times, when you die you feel that wasn’t your fault, but bad level design, controls or mechanics. Now, it seems that I’m being harsh at the game, but it’s only because you can see that it wants to be a great platformer. But in the end, it’s still a good, cheap game, and I can recommend it if you enjoy the genre. The visuals and soundtrack are pretty nice, but even the best song in my opinion is unfortunately present in swimming focused levels, where the music gets muffled, wasting it.

7/10 – Use A Potion!

This is more of a "Dark Souls" of trying not to hurl, I say.

I thought this would be a very fun and challenging platformer, instead, I got a headache and dizzy from the intro bit before the game even began. I realized later that I can change the screen rotation speed, but that still didn't sit well with my stomach. I may be one of a minority who just can't get over that hump, oh well.

This game has some neat ideas, and heavily reminded me of Super Mario Galaxy. I do think the artistic aspect of the game is rather well done. The controls are unique as well, and the physics is clearly done very well. I couldn't play enough levels to really comment on the game play though... I think I did manage 2 levels beyond the introductory levels, but the nausea was just not worth it for me.

40415694.review:
I first came across Airscape when I volunteered to help test Linux builds. Without being aware that the game had won Best Use of Game Physics in Intel's Level Up competition and was selected to be showcased at GDC, PAX Australia, PAX East, PAX Prime, and the Boston Festival of Indie Games, my initial impressions were that it would be a widely loved game.

I assumed that its gorgeous graphics, orchestral soundtrack and cute characters would bring people in, and its difficulty curve would make sure it would be offering players months and years' worth of well designed challenges to explore.

It turns out, however, that Airscape: The Fall of Gravity would not receive much attention at launch from press or players. When developer Daniel West wrote a Gamasutra article talking about how he'd ticked all of the boxes for the, "Oh, you should've done X," type dismissive non-actionable retrospective advice offered to unsuccessful developers titled [url=http://cheesetalks.net/www.gamasutra.com/blogs/DanielWest/20150908/253040/Good_isnt_good_enough__releasing_an_indie_game_in_2015.php]'Good' Isn't Good Enough[/url], the response he received was generally in the form of criticism of the game coupled with a veiled assertion that it's not appropriate for developers to voice concerns like this, coming from people who come across as not existing within its audience (as an aside, I'd hoped the article would generate discussion on how that kind of advice isn't particularly helpful and that there must be better ways to handle and mitigate disappointing launches, but it didn't).

With about 25 hours on either side of the game's release, I still find the game's level design to be its best feature. Even though the gravity mechanics may seem simple at first, the game presents a number of variations that allow for a consistently fresh array of movement challenges across the game's 60+ level campaign.

[i]This was originally written as part of [url=http://cheesetalks.net/gamesRoundup2015.php]a retrospective[/url] on games I finished in 2015.[/i]


[b]Addendum[/b]: Since writing this, Steam distribution rights for the game were sold to a third party, whose handling of the game causes me concern and are worth making note of.

1. The new distributor would spam the game's announcements with news about their other games (Subterra and Road Redemption). These are now hidden from the store page/user notifications, but two can still be seen [url=http://store.steampowered.com/news/?appids=317250]here[/url]
2. The new distributor lowered the minimum system requirements for Windows below what it will reasonably run on (original developer's comments on this can be found [url=http://steamcommunity.com/app/317250/discussions/0/541907867790909664/#c350543951935747029]here[/url], [url=http://cheesetalks.net/images/2015played/airscapesysreq.png]screenshot[/url]), at the same time as setting 85+% discounts
3. The new distributor added an ad oriented launcher with a difficult to see "play" button to the Windows version of the game. Some posts discussing this have been deleted, but at the time of writing, there is remaining discussion [url=http://steamcommunity.com/app/317250/discussions/0/135509823669651564/]here[/url]

If any of those make a prospective player uncomfortable, the game is also available on the Humble Store, where the original developer still holds distribution rights and receives money for their work.

39082317.review:
Ok, I recommend this game , especially for the price you can get it at on sale. But, with some serious reservations, see my pros and cons.

Pros:

Level design is exceptional
Manages to be original with gameplay despite an increasingly crowded genre
Graphics/sound/all other bells and whistles are very nice

Cons:

Level of difficulty is in the "so hard it's no longer fun" realm (except at the very beginning)
-- My biggest problem with this is the way the creators accomplished this. They either add environmental elements that are entirely random (i.e., eliminates the actual challenge of a platformer which is muscle memory and makes it largely about chance), or by making your character almost impossible to control. The ladder is kind of fun IF YOU LIKE THAT KIND OF THING, the former almost made me not recommend the game.

This is only a platformer by a VERY loose definition, all the later levels involve significant modifications to control and environment that mean most of the time you are not jumping from platform to platform.

38251356.review:
Like octopuses and masochistic 2D platformers? then sit down and keep the barf bag handy. [i]Airscape - The Fall of Gravity[/i] is the story of your mild mannered dumbo octopus sucked out of the water and unceremoniously burdened with the rescue of his family and fellow sea critters from the merciless vice of bad robo. Your octopus will flip upside down as you traverse floating landmasses and water globs changing gravitational pulls in the process which will be nauseating despite a snappiness slider to lessen the discomfort of which I found little to no relief. Somehow I would strap my guts and leap my way from challenge to challenge all the while gritting my teeth. “You can't possible complete these levels and free the many creatures while inching your way death by agonizing death” scoffed the game. “Oh can't I?” my petulant retort, as I would proceed to spend 4.5 hours bashing my squishy dumbo mantle against steel wall time and time again, which was easy with a quick restart after a death and quick level jumps. Something of a stroke would happen and I would fine myself a dozen levels further finding joy in the “tennis smash” sound whenever you save a critter from being a Christmas ornament forever. It did feel like a real challenge with rapidly improving arsenal of death aimed at your squishy ear-flapped head and the cumulative inclusion of every weapon you've faced denotes the thorough planning in this platformer. The soundtrack is enjoyable, and has a muffling effect as you enter water, which I felt only added to my dizziness. In all if you find this game on sale and want to throw up a bit or whittle some time by yourself give this game a try.   

TLDR
Dumbo Octopus Gauntlet Biathlon of Death
+trippy physics utilized creatively
+nice soundtrack
+short

-barfy physics
-addictive

Aliens kidnapped your aquatic friends. Are you a bad enough octopus to rescue them all?

A cool little mind-bending platformer that takes advantage of rotating levels. You play as a cute orange octopus and have to collect the MacGuffins in each level to proceed. It starts off as an easy platformer, but quickly kneecaps you when it's done teaching you the mechanics. If you like tricky platformers with a little twist, this is a solid game. It's also on sale all the damn time and was a commercial flop when it first launched, but I think word-of-mouth has vindicated it since then.

If you're worried about motion sickness, you can adjust the screen rotation as much as you want (and you can snap the camera to level it out).

This is probably one of Steam's hidden gems. From the very start it gave me some Mario Galaxy vibes, and I was right when I found myself floating around tiny planets and doing seemingly impossible jumps. Also, this game is tough, a lot; you have to constantly look around for enemies and obstacles which may even come from above, gravity affects how everything moves. But at the end, I found myself wanting to go through every level possible and see how harder it could actually get. As a side note, I need to warn you about the game camera, which is constantly moving and may make you feel dizzy; but it's actually something difficult to avoid when the game is about changing perspectives every second.

Anyhow, this game is worth the money, Steam Sales or not.

STORY: 

The story of Airscape from what i understood is that it all starts with you controlling a squid and your with your other squid family, fishes, crabs, and other different sea creatures. It was all peaceful until a bomb exlosion happens and an alien robot thing captures your squid family and the rest of your fellow sea creatures and you have to go and save them from the alien race. Okay the story seems simple enough where the player will get the entire gist of it. Its a simple goal and it  works but the problem there is that its overused, Usual story plots of platformers is that something bad happens and you stop it, its been used alot the only difference i found in it is the fact instead of being a robot kid person (Megaman, sorry for low rated comparison), a plumber (Mario), a hedehog (sonic) your......a squid. Thats it, save your family beat the main villain poof thats it 

GAMEPLAY:

Gameplay wise, Airscape has its own way of traversing through its levels, the levels are suited and well thought of in order to make use of the abilities your squid character has. Plus with all its other aspects like swimming while avoiding bombs and rockets, the twisty, tilting camera, Zero Gravity stages and more, you can fairly say that airscape has its own thing going for them. Another thing about it is its stages. some stages are forgiving and make you play calmly while emjoying the animated art the game has but others are really difficult. The difficulty can make a person rage from time to time (which i did mostly) The stages are layed out differently between areas (Zones) with each zone having a specialty, some are normal but others like the swimming stages, zero gravity stages, toxic stages etc, are designed to make your rage a few times. Another aspect i like in the game is being able to switch between the characters you unlocked, which makes you feel like a team when approaching your objective. 

CONTROLS:

The games controls are easy to remember which the arrow keys being the movement, spacebar to jump and shift to run 
but the way the controls feel when your playing some of the stages such as the unerwater it tends to be way difficult. sometimes it feels delayed or it feels as if the game cheated you but knowing your the one who was the reason you screwed up. The player may also use a controller which helps in some levels. all what i can say is, some levels work with a controller and some work with a keyboard so its all about preferences. 

OVERALL:

The game is good, its good enough to call it a platforming game, but its something that you would play once, finish it and never reinstall because of how pissed you are at the game. But please i would say try it out for yourself its a platformer with its own styles and creativity which makes it feel like its not one of those cliche Games. For people who like platformers i would like you to try the game out and create your own expereience

34770154.review:
Airscape is a difficult platformer about an octopus on a quest to save his friends with emphasis on gravity based controls.

[Pros]
+Fun
+Objectives add additional challenge if you want it
+Responsive Controls
+Cute Art
+Creative mechanics/use of gravity
+Cheap

[Cons]
-Disjoint in expected difficulty vs actual difficulty
-Some enemy types are very obnoxious (more on this below)
-Gravity fields aren't obvious, and you can occasionally be flung in a direction you weren't expecting
-Some levels equate to trial and error rather than observe and react

I'd have to say the enemies/obstacles are my biggest complaint. Particularly the gun. It's a basic unit that if it's lazer sights lay on you for too long, it will fire and send you back to the checkpoint. The problem is execution. The enemy type requires you to move a certain distance per second across the guns point of view to keep from being locked on, but there are parts of the game where you are swimming and your turn -> accelerate speed is just too slow. The most taxing moments in the game for me were mostly gun related.

My other main frustration was never knowing which direction I'd be sent when I jumped out of a pool of water. 

Overall, I enjoyed the game enough to 101% it after just 106%'ing Super Meat Boy.

34743535.review:
Great music, great animations, overall simple gameplay, a good amount of content, good physics, very charming, and nice variety.

So why do I not recommend this?
Ultimately, it comes down to the game being tediously difficult at times:
1. My greatest issue with the game is *why* it is difficult.  In other fast-paced platformer games like Sonic, Mario, Super Meat Boy, or Element4l, your success is solely based on your skill and ability to keep up your momentum.  Everything is positioned in a way where if you time yourself correctly, you'll get through very smoothly.  This game is not like that.  Assuming there is a fast and fluid way to beat each level, the enemies and obstacles won't be in their correct positions if you respawn at a checkpoint.  But the real underlying issue is there are WAY too many situations where the obstacles are out-of-sync.  For example, there are times where you have to wait for lasers to turn off in order to pass, but there could be a moving platform where if you don't get on it on time, you miss your shot.  So you sit there waiting, not knowing when you're SUPPOSED to go, because the exact moment won't come up again until an unknown amount of time.  Considering how un-forgiving this game is of the slightest mistakes, this just needlessly wastes time.
2. Gravity is VERY inconsistent.  Some chunks of land (regardless of their size or material) will pull you toward them, while others won't.
3. The way you move in water is very different from on land.  Normally this doesn't bother me, except in this game you're under pressure to make very precise moves very quickly, all while the camera angle might change as you switch between in and out of water.  Also, the blue octopus teleports forward in water, but outside of water it teleports left or right.  In levels with toxic water where you need to splash on the surface to stay alive, this gets extremely annoying.
4. Some may find the camera dizzying, but to me the real problem is sometimes it zooms in too close, and I can't tell where I'm going.  I often died because I didn't know where I was supposed to go.
5. Though the fan physics are fine, they are (in my opinion) the hardest mechanic to master. The game doesn't give you many opportunities to train yourself.  So, by the time you REALLY need to know how to master it, you just keep dying.
6. Sometimes, you rotate too slowly in water.  There are moments where you have to outrun a fast-moving target and outrun a timed laser all while you're swimming in toxic water.  Meanwhile, the path you have to take is ~120 degrees off from your facing direction.  It's annoyingly hard to get your timing done just right when the octopus rotates so slowly.
7. The game adds obstacles as an artificial way of increasing the difficulty.  Sometimes I'm presented with an already modest challenge, but the devs decide to throw in something like mines for the hell of it.  The additional mines don't further test your skill, they're just simply tedious.  Reminds me of Contra or Battletoads - if you like ripping your hair out over the slightest mistake, sure, maybe this isn't a problem for you, but I find it unnecessary.  A good platformer relies on your precision and ability to time yourself, a bad one will just simply hurt your luck.


I feel most of my gripes could easily be fixed with just 4 simple tweaks:
A. For any time-sensitive obstacles, make sure everything is synchronized, so you don't have to guess when is the right time to go; you'll just know.  At that point it is up to the player to have the skill to make it to the end.  In most cases, the obstacles don't have to change at all, they just move or toggle at a different pace.  This addresses problem 1.
B. You play as octopuses: animals that have suction cups and are known to walk on walls.  There's no need to have micro-gravity effects - just have the octopus able to walk on [some] walls.  In most parts of the game, this wouldn't have any effect on the level design. This would resolve problem 2.
C. Have the camera always oriented with gravity, which in turns makes the swimming direction absolute rather than relative.  This would solve problems 3, 4, and 6, and could make problem 2 a little less extreme.  This too would have little to no effect on level design.
D. To address problem 7, have an "easy" and "normal" mode, where easy removes some of the excess traps, and maybe gives you a half-second extra for things like toxic water or the laser-mounted rifles.

34691713.review:
[h1]Great game, probably terrible code[/h1]
[i]Yes, I just wrote this to rant[/i]

Gameplay-wise, super-neat game. It's fun, it's fair but hard, it's well designed, the player can quickly understand how things work, all is well.

The music is also fantastic. [i]Hypothetically.[/i]

The graphics are also neat. [i]Hypothetically.[/i]

Why did I put graphical and musical quality into an hypothesis?

Well, regarding the graphics, because I may not have the best machine... In fact is just an average-tier professional laptop. But I know how to properly optimize my computer resources, and I have run flawlessy through games far more complex. I can run most Unreal games on High quality, same goes for Unity, and same goes for Source games. bUt ThIs ThInG decided to divide my resolution by ~=8 (at least it looked like it as the terrain got paved with phat pixels). In fact the resolution got so low, I could see light blue lines passing by the edge of each blob of water. I know why this can happen, and this quite the unprofessional mistake. Though I guess I can't blame the devs since they didn't write their engine.

Regarding the music (any sound, actually), every something time, the sound would start crackling and muffling, and this effect would intensify until I get out of a body of water. My guess is that they forgot to remove the water sound filter when you exit a body of water by respawning. So if you happen to stumble on a segment where you die in the first body of water after a checkpoint, your sound will slowly morph from a symphony, to a muffled symphony, to a muder attempt against your sound card, to just getting mute. This would easily be fixed and frankly, shouldn't be a thing.

So do I recommend this game? Yes, if your PC can run it ridiculously smoothly on ultra, and you're good enough to never die in a body of water after a checkpoint. </s>

Don't buy this. Just follow this game and wait for a news post saying that the devs got their shit together.

34561705.review:
I haven't even finished the second world and already there's too many glaring flaws for me to recommend this game to anyone even at its low price. First off, this game's main selling point (the screen turning with freely rotating gravity) seems appealing at first but may cause dizziness or just be awkward once you actually play under it. Additionally, a mute octopus is not a really relatable protagonist no matter what you do with him, let alone with no plot at all. Plus, this is a highly linear action platformer, and a slow-moving one too, with no puzzle or metroidvania elements.

Even for those who like it, the underwater intro before you get kidnapped shows off a lot of flaws even beyond that. The physics are slippery even for video game water physics, the graphics (like those in the rest of the game) are generic platformer graphics, there's no clear indication whether the other sea creatures around you are friend or foe, the screen may randomly shift so you have to mash the up button to escape, you're not even told the sideways controls until the first level proper, you'll probably wander around aimlessly for several seconds before being kidnapped, and once you're kidnapped you're not even shown entering the UFO that kidnapped you and your marine pals.

That intro still doesn't capture all the flaws with this game. Some of the rescuable sea creatures get kidnapped by the aliens if you take too long, there's no indication which ones or how long you have to rescue them, some are at the end of very sluggish levels, and the easiest way of making them available again is killing yourself. The game is as hard as it's billed as, but by modern standards that difficulty is in large part not the fair kind.

34000649.review:
It's like they took the Raphael the Raven boss fight from Yoshi's Island and made a whole game out of it. That's great, because that was the best part of Yoshi's Island. 

The game looks cutesy but that only fools you into thinking it's childish or easy. You do get infinite lives, but on the other hand you'll be experiencing infinite deaths too. The premise is you're a little octopus and aliens have sucked up your part of the ocean, including you and all your sea buddies. You unlock more stages by freeing things like crabs, jellyfish, and shrimps held captive throughout the levels. This is nice because it means you can finish the game by getting enough creatures in the early levels without having to actually beat every stage, and some of the later ones you'll probably be happy to skip since they can get insane. Lasers, homing missiles, bullet hell segments, all while spinning around in a floating bubble of water. It's a lot for one octopus to handle, but it's all in good fun. Every few stages you enter a fortress to free another octopus relative that has a special ability, like double jump, briefly slow down time, or perform a short teleport. There are checkpoints and you can try as much as you want so it doesn't become infuriatingly difficult. The final boss is really cool too. It reminds me a little of Portal, only more underwater. 

A+ game, please go buy it, it's really great and unique.

33398001.review:
Nota: 5/10

Hablar de un analisis profundo de este juego (en opinion muy personal) me resulta imposible, porque no fui capaz de terminarlo, aun asi, con el poco tiempo de juego que logre provarlo intentare dar una review imparcial y que resulte util a otros usuarios.

Puntos Positivos:
-El apartado visual si bien no es exepcional, me resulto muy agradable, el tratamiento de escenarios es muy simple pero cumple con lo deseable y lo concidero apropiado para la tematica del juego.

-Concepto innovador y con potencial, la idea de los controles me parece muy interesante, y tiene mucho potencial, se puede lograr muchas cosas interesantes con el.

-Sencillo, con esto me refiero a la clarida del juego, no es pretencioso o no esta plagado de mecanicas innecesarias, va directo a lo que debe sin pasar por puntos de mas.

Puntos Negativos:

-Control, desconosco si gran parte de los problemas de control en mi experiencia fueron causados por el siguente punto que voy a mencionar(con el cual este esta relacionado estrechamente) , pero estoy seguro que el juego abusa demaciado de algunos puntos, como por ejemplo la inercia del movimiento dentro de las zonas con agua, llegando a tal punto que es frustrante de mala manera, sintiendose una muy poca exactitud a la hora de hacer movimientos. 

Por el genero de plataformas concidero que es de vital importancia que los controles esten bien calibrados y resulten manejables, desconozco completamente si la intencion de provocar que el movimiento fuera tan complicado fue de caracter intencional, pero en mi opinion solo agrega dificultad innecesaria y artificial al titulo.

-El movimiento de camara(pantalla), este es el principal motivo por el cual no fui capaz de terminarlo, como antes mencionaba esto es parte de los controles, pero me da la imprecion de que el movimiento (para ser mas especificos la velocidad) esta muy mal calibrado, a tal punto que no pude pasar mas de un par de minutos sin terminar con un fuerte dolor de cabeza.

La mecanica por la cual se mueve la camara en lugar del personajes para elegir la direcion tiene mucho potencial, pero si se hace de forma incorrecta solo genera problemas para el usuario, en este caso, a mi parecer este es el procipal problema del juego.

Conclusion: El juego presenta una propuesta muy interesante sobre los plataformas, pero los controles son ejecutados de tal manera que no hacen mas que resulta incomodos y molestos para la experiencia de juego, seguramente algunas personas no encuentren tan molesto el movimiento, pero concidero que es muy mejorable. No recomiendo el juego, en especial a las personas con problemas de orientacion o equilibrio, esto podria reuslta en una experiencia especialmente desagradable para ellos. Si tu no sufres de ningun problema con esto, podrias darle una oportunidad, pero mi recomendacion es que esperes a alguna rebaja.

33370832.review:
I have around two hours of “”Airscape - The Fall of Gravity” as of writing this review, but so far I have found this to be an excellent game. I brings in a bunch of interesting mechanics that personally, I have never seen before, and it introduces those concepts in simple, yet clever ways that need little to no text whatsoever. An example of this is when they introduce buttons, they start off by putting you in a closed room with a door, and a button, showing you what the buttons in this game do before you get to the more complicated parts. I wish more games introduced concepts in simpler ways like this game does

At first, I thought this game was going to be way too easy, but as I got further in I discovered that not to be the case. It gradually gets more difficult as it goes, but it doesn't spike up the difficulty in a way that makes me want to quit playing altogether.

Some people may have a slight issue with the rotation of the screen, but despite the very helpful slider that decreases, or increases the rate of rotation, I can see why some people might have a problem with this. If you have extreme motion sickness I would sadly say this would not be your best option, but you could always get it to see if the slider works for you, and if it doesn't there is no shame in refunding this game

The soundtrack in this game is simply  phenomenal, I simply love them and got the OST (original soundtrack) right away, just so I could listen to it everywhere I go. Usually I play my own music behind games, but for this one I just had to close Spotify.

What I also adore about this game is the graphical style. The terrain, water, and the characters 
You play as, are all beautifully created. They are both simple, yet elegant at the same time and I wish I could make graphics that look as great as these do

The controls are very smooth and simple, and even though I have yet to play this with a controller, I can tell it is one of those rare games that use the controller to it’s fullest potential.


Overall with my relatively short experience with game, it has quickly become one of my top games and I wish I played this sooner despite me buying this back in November of 2016, and it is one of those rare gems of a game that you simply have to play, especially with it’s extremely cheap $2.19 CAD price tag.

33043641.review:
Airscape: the Fall of Gravity is a weird 2D gravity-changing platformer. You play as an adorable little octopus, who is just trying to save his friends from the evil robots and go home. As you progress, you save more of your octopus buddies, which corresponds to unlocking different "skins" with alternate abilities. And, of course, the levels get much harder the further you go on.

I liked Airscape. Early on, it felt a little weird and rough around the edges, but I definitely grew more fond of it as I played. Like I said before, it does get harder, and there are some levels that are pretty difficult. Nothing on the hardest levels of super meat boy or similar, but definitely up there. Mechanically, the game was pretty sound. There were a few strange bugs with gravity shifting unexpectedly, specifically when it came to ledges that you shouldn't be able to stand on but could, but other than that, it was definitely fine for an indie developer AND for the price point.

Ultimately, I think that this game is probably not going to be appealing to a lot of people, just because it's basically another platformer with a twist. But if you like those styles of games, or if you liked the gravity shenanigans of Super Mario Galaxy, then I would certainly recommend it!

Beautiful, fun and frustrating. In my humble opinion, this game has everything a good platformer should have and something more. The biggest hook for me was the gravity mechanics, which at first was very disorienting and weird, but once you get used to it, it really enriches the gameplay.

For a platformer, the graphics is really great. Individual zones are different and refreshing, while being very pleasing to the eye and the water also looks good.
It also has a full orchestreal soundtrack, which can get very annoying when you are struggling with a hard level, but neverthless a great audio!

As for the difficulty, at first I thought this was some short of kid platformer, but from the zone 9 onwards it was sometimes a neverending nightmare. Some levels have unbelievable difficulty, but the checkpoint system is fair and even after numerous tries, it does not get boring.

It took me a while to get all the achievements, but it was definitely worth it and I had a great fun doing it.

All in all, if you like platformers and are not intimidated by difficult games, this should definitely find place in your Steam library.

31580598.review:
Airscape is the greatest platformer you’ve never played.  Take the traditional stage-based 2D precision platformer.  Add in the gravitational relativity of Mario Galaxy.  Now split the game into 15 worlds, give each world its own gimmick, and give each level its own special take on that gimmick, and only the surface has been scratched of what Airscape has to offer.
 
The level variety is astounding.  The gravitational relativity allows for levels to be linear, circular, vertical, amorphous, or all manner of other shapes never seen before (aided by the fact that water isn’t affected by gravity at all). There’s piles of different enemies, traps, and interactable objects in the game, each with important different mechanics, and so many that some are only ever seen in two or three of the 50+ levels.  Levels are long and complex enough that each obstacle is used to its full extent once it shows up, so nothing ever feels like its potential was wasted, nor is anything reused so much it wears out its welcome.  But be careful; Airscape is a true precision platformer, and the difficulty is very firm!  However, the difficulty curve is gracious, and offers the player a lot of easy levels up front to get used to things before turning on the heat.
 
In a nigh-unheard of move for a precision platformer, Airscape also has five very different characters to play: one moves faster, one has floaty jumps, one can teleport short distances, one can slow down the game speed, and one has a double-jump.  Despite these drastic differences all levels can still be completed with any character, and there’s no clear “best” pick, just different playstyles to suit a player’s preferences.  The character selection is a testament to the game’s robustness, as each level had to be designed with all five playstyles in mind to avoid game-breaking exploits while still being appropriately difficult, and it succeeds handily in that regard.
 
No review of this game would be a true review without giving praise to the glorious background music.  Throughout the game are beautiful, sweeping orchestral melodies that rival what any big-budget production brings to the table.  Each track elicits a different emotion perfect for the visual style of the world at hand, and while a player might pick out their “best” song, they’d be very hard-pressed to pick out their worst.

No review can really do this game justice: it is the real deal.  It does everything it sets out to do, and does so much more while doing it.

31453750.review:
Well this game sucks. I was expecting something like Mario Galaxy, and I guess in a sense that's what it is. But it's a very disorientating and a poorly executed interpretation of Mario Galaxy. It could have been a great game but there are several critical issues working against it.

The first issue is the combination of the camera and the controls. Naturally the camera always rotates so it appears as if you're standing straight up. And that works well enough while you're on the ground, but when you're swimming, the controls switch to a completely different setup. Left and right now rotate the camera instead of controlling which direction you're trying to move your character. So it doesn't feel like you're controlling your character anymore so much as you're trying to steer him while he rockets forward. So switching back and forth between the two control setups in a pinch is very disorientating, and considering how many of the levels have you switching back and forth very quickly, it very frequently results in a death.

I should point out it's possible to adjust how fast the camera rotates. It's based on a percentage, with 0% being no camera rotation, and 200% being the fastest speed. But anything that's not 200% or 0% is a waste of time because who wants a camera that can only slowly rotate to the direction you're facing? That seems like it would only add to the disorientation. Thankfully the developers had the good sense to let you adjust this on the fly with keybindings, but this means the developers clearly knew this was an issue, and couldn't/wouldn't fix it.

The next issue is the difficulty. It scales up too quickly. The first few levels are a joyous half-hearted romp through the park on a mild Saturday afternoon. By level 11, you have to dodge missiles, landmines, tanks with chainsaws, lasers, and killer UFOs while trying to reach a location at the top of a broken path to collect a thing before it's gone forever because there's a time limit. All the while you have to switch back and forth between the two disorientating control setups because there's chunks of land and bodies of water you're required to maneuver through. And considering how short the levels are, that is a very sharp difficulty increase.

What's interesting is you can unlock different characters, but the bizarre part is the new character appears to be a complete improvement on the previous. Once you unlock the purple character, there is no reason at all to use orange. So why do they even bother letting you switch back to him? It should just be a new ability for the previous character.

Honestly I could overlook all of this game's issues, including the fact you can't rebind the very necessary run key, which means if you keep your hand on the home row like an adult and need to run to the left, you get to eat shit. And don't expect that to get fixed any time soon because the developers were informed of this a year or so ago and there's been no response from them on the matter. But even that would be forgivable if not for the biggest issue of all:

You only have one health point. This above all else is what kills the experience for me. With all of the disorientating camera rotations, disorientating control changes, disorientating level designs, missile dodging, landmine dodging, tank with chainsaw dodging, laser dodging, killer UFO dodging, and absurdly short time limits, would having more than 1 health point really break gameplay? Would it really be so terrible if I could take one free hit before having to restart the whole level all over again because I didn't reach the thing before it disappeared forever? [b]Having only one health point is expecting a lot of discipline from the player, while the game itself shows no discipline of its own.[/b] Fix your camera and control issues first, then you can punish me for not navigating your disorientating levels fast enough.

In short, I give Disorientation: The Disorientating Strikes Back a disorientating disorientation out of 10.

31410521.review:
I wanted to like Airscape: The Fall of Gravity but couldn't. The trappings are nice but the gameplay is poor, regrettably as it has potential.

Cute and clean graphics [i]can[/i] pose a welcome opposition to hard platforming gameplay. The problem with Airscape: The Fall of Gravity is that it clearly goes overboard with its difficulty, instead of hard but engaging it's outright malevolent. The leveldesign is such that it requires no less than pixel perfect platforming while the controls and physics needed for that are not up to the task.

When it comes to precise platforming, I feel it is necessary to give the player exact control in a comprehensible environment. This ensures that the player is completely responsible for his triumph as well as failure. Unfortunately, despite trying a fair bit, I was unable to replicate a control pattern, the game is too floaty and elusive. It's such a darling game otherwise if only navigation was just a little bit more tangible.

I would recommend Airscape: The Fall of Gravity only to the hardcorest platform lovers. The level of masochism required to complete this game is simply too high, even in comparison to other difficult indie titles like VVVVVV.

(Completed 16 levels of 60+, progressed up to zone 9 of 18)

30176591.review:
Airscape is a platform game about a couple of alien octopus which are kidnapped from their home town and need to fight for survival.

[h1] Graphics[/h1] 
The graphics are really good for an indie game. The multiple colors blend nicely, creating a nice view for your eyes. The quality is not the best, but this is not a bad thing, because the game is nice for its simplicity.

[h1] Gameplay[/h1] 
The gameplay is really easy to learn, like the overall of platform games: you move,  jump and, dash and you can also float a little when you jump if you keep the jump button pressed. The levels start easy and start to get really tough when you progress through the game. Your octopus is reallty fragile, because only one enemy hit will kill him, so you will die A LOT here. Fortunatelly, you have infinite lives and you start at the last checkpoint you used.

The interface has a map which you can roam freely at it, without needing to go through a fixed path, until you go to the level of your choice. At each level, you collect until 3 items which are used to unlock some special areas where you can unlock new octopus to play with. They are different colors and I have unlocked the blue one so far. Probably they are a little different to use, but I'm not sure, because I unlocked only one.

The difference of this game to other platforms is the gravity theme: a little like Mario Galaxy, you'll get to some places where you'll upside down, pushed by the gravity of some places and this sometimes can be kind of annoying. Fortunatelly, it's a minor issue and it doesn't affect the gameplay.

[h1] Audio & Soundtrack[/h1] 
The soundtrack is simple, yet beautiful, without being annoying. It's composed of relaxing tones so you feel at ease.

[h1]Storyline[/h1] 
As a plartform game, the story usually is really simple, because there's no need to understand it in order to play. You are controling alien octopus kidnapped by an unknow force and need to survive throuygh the levels. That's all you know so far.

[h1]The veredict[/h1]
It's a nice and relaxing platform game, with easy controls, but with levels getting harder when you progress through the game. I really enjoyed and would recommend for any platform game fans. Grab this game while at a sale if you are uncertain about it, you won't regret.

[h1]Rating:[/h1]
Graphics: 8/10
Audio: 8/10
Gameplay: 8,5/10
Overall: 8/10

Airscape really surprised me, I bought it on special for under a dollar and was expecting a cheap little game to spend a day or two on, I actually ended up getting a fast paced challenging game at a steal of a price that kept me busy for quite a while.
At first it seems pretty basic and the controls/camera movements feel a little weird, but once you get the rhythm of the game down it really is a blast. It has kind of a Meatboy feel to it, but the underwater controls bring a whole new dimension and a plethora of new challenges to the game which I hadn’t expected in a platformer like this. 
I’ve always been kind of a completionist so games like this, with achievements, items to get in each level, and unlockable characters, tend to really grab my attention. Getting every ‘critter’ (3 in each level) was really a challenge, finding them can range from an easy jump to speed running through a level at impossible speeds, some of them require a certain character or precise timing; suffice to say you won’t be able to complete the game 100% without a challenge.

Tl;dr : challenging game with unique controls and plenty of unlockables /achievements to keep you busy, well worth the price.

29700664.review:
Edit: Holy lord this game gets difficult. Just beat the regular game after a year and a half hiatus, and after unlocking the final, extra world, I decided to quit because the time it takes to complete each level and die a hundred times in the same exact parts tilts the scale into the not-having-fun area of gaming. All that said, for a $5 game, this gets a 9/10 from me. If you happen to find it on sale for $.50, you need to play it. 


Good: 

*Challenging  - Reminiscent of Super Meat Boy, though somehow not as rewarding. Controls are tight; most, if not all, deaths are your fault.
*Clever Level Designs - Some levels felt phoned in, but MANY took advantage of the game's cool gravity mechanic. Not to mention, the different worlds vary in atmosphere greatly, which is very nice.
*Adjustable motion rotation for camera - I turned mine up all the way, and only a couple of moments made me dizzy. The option is still there to turn it down if you are susceptible to motion sickness.
*Ambience - Music and graphics fit well together. They don't bring the game down.
*Sale price - So cheap. Definitely worth $0.49. I'd have paid full price if I knew I'd enjoy it as much as I do (still only $5). 

Bad:

*Exhausting - Being challenging can be a bad quality, too. I've been able to play 3 sessions, a half hour each. There's a reason most reviews you see for this game are 3 hours or fewer. Every moment requires your full attention and hard concentration. Not the kind of game to spend an afternoon on, or to play while watching a movie or TV show on Netflix.

If you like platformers, there's no reason you shouldn't try this one out.
